prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
For your voice is a river, quietly carving stone,
Your whisper the wind’s patient hand on the mountain’s brow.
To hear you, I must silence my own clamor,
Let the echo of certainty dissolve in your clear stream.

I will pause at the threshold of every opinion,
Hold judgment like a stone that might bruise a seed,
And wait for your gentle footfall in the hush of dawn.
Perhaps then your syllables will settle in my marrow,
And words, when spoken, will spring from true ground.

For only in the habit of listening to you, Truth,
Can my tongue be trusted with your subtle flame—a quiet lamp
Lit not by my will, but by the patience of hearing.
So teach me to listen, until at last I may speak you,
Not as a master of knowing, but a servant of understanding.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I let your quiet footsteps echo in my heart,
If I unclasp my fears and let your silence through,
Then speech will bloom where wisdom has its start.

You are not thunder shouted from the tallest tower,
Nor the clamor of certainty that blinds the mind;
You are the hidden root, the patient, subtle flower,
Growing where humility and openness entwined.

So I will learn to listen before I speak your name,
To recognize your presence in the hush between the words,
Habituate my soul to seek you, never tame,
Let the music of your honesty in every note be heard.

Only then, Truth, may I give you voice sincere:
A tongue tuned by listening, a heart that holds you near.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not as one who claims you, but as one who waits:
A patient ear, open to your subtle arrival,
Learning the rhythm of your honest gait.

You slip through silence, elusive and pure,
A shadow in the hush before dawn’s first light.
I must quiet the noise of my own desire,
Let your whisper become my guiding sight.

To speak you, Truth, is not to shout or seize,
But to listen, deeply, to what is unseen.
To listen is to honor the space you need,
So when you come, my words are clean.

So make me a vessel, emptied of pride,
Habituated to listening, with nothing to hide.
Then, when I speak, let it be you revealed,
Truth, in the habit of listening, healed.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I clear the cobwebs of my certainty and let your voice ring through.
You are not found in the thunder of declarations,
But in the gentle rain that nourishes patient fields.

I must unlearn the urge to hurry, the need to be first,
And cultivate the quiet where your seeds take root.
Only then, in the hush between questions and answers,
Can I hear your subtle heartbeat and carry it into speech.

Let my tongue be trained by your quiet counsel;
Let my heart grow humble enough to wait for you.
For only in the habit of listening—truly listening—
Will my words echo the dignity you deserve.

So come, Truth, to my attentive ear, and teach me,
That I might speak you with the fidelity of one who has heard.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Let my ears be open as the dawn to your gentle arrival.
Too often, I chase your shadow, forging words unmeasured,
But you linger in the quiet, patient, and unadorned.

Let me learn your language hidden between the lines,
Hear your call in silence, in pauses, in what is not said.
May I unweave my pride, and attend to your soft instruction,
So that when I give voice, it is truly you that is heard.

To make a habit of listening, I must set aside my armor,
Let humility be my companion, and curiosity my guide.
For only then, Truth, will my words be clear as morning water,
And my tongue, a faithful echo of your light.

Speak, and I will listen; listen, and I will speak you,
In the circle of honest hearts, where habit becomes virtue.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:

If I’ve tuned my ear to your quietest note,

Perhaps then the words that I utter will keep

The shape of your honesty, undistorted and clear—
For truth is not spoken only, but learned when we hear.
So, let me be patient, let me be still;
Let me listen to you, Truth, and be guided until

My voice, when it rises, rings faithful and true—
A reflection, at last, of the listening I do.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not in the thunder of declarations, but in the hush between words.
You wait for me in the silent pause, the space where pride dissolves—
A patient teacher, you urge me to unclench my fists,

If I would speak you, I must surrender my stories,
Sit with discomfort, and listen for your quiet knock.

May I be brave enough to hear you—
To let you change me before I name you out loud.
In learning to listen, may my words ring true:
Truth, I shall speak you, for I have learned you in silence.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
How often have I heard your voice, muffled beneath my fears?
Yet, in the quiet hours, when pretense falls away,

Teach me, then, to listen—
To pause before answering, to weigh each word,
To let your light sift through my tangled thoughts.
Only then, when I have learned your subtle language,
May I become your vessel, not your jailer.

Let me be humble in your presence,
Knowing that to speak you is to first surrender.
Let my tongue gather your clarity,
So when I open my lips, you are there—
Undistorted, unbroken, bright as the morning air.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not just in the echo chamber of my own mind,
But in the quiet between other hearts, in the patience of waiting.
To listen is to humble myself before your subtle shape,
To accept you even when your form unsettles me.

You are not always the loudest voice, nor the most convenient.
You arrive in fragments—soft, persistent, true—
And I must gather them, arrange them, and learn their meaning.

Only then can I hope to carry your message,
To let my words become a vessel for your light.
Let me listen first, and speak only after,
So that what I say bears the weight of your wisdom,
And Truth, you are honored in the habits of my tongue.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
For only in the quiet, attentive mind does your form reveal itself.
You are the river that carves stone, patient and clear,
Not always loud, but ever-present for those who attend.

If I learn to listen—really listen—
To the tremor beneath the words, the silence after the question,
Then perhaps my speech will mirror your clarity.
May my heart be open, my mind uncluttered,
So that when you whisper, I am ready.

And when I speak, let it be with the weight of your presence,
Not the noise of my ignorance or pride.
For truth, you are a companion for the humble,
A guide for those who dare to listen first.
Let me listen well, so I may speak you true.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee—  
The moon resigns her silver light,  
The stars grow dim in reverie,  
And dawn delays the coming night.  

No rose, no song, no ocean's plea  
Could tempt my heart to turn away;  
All beauty finds its source in thee,  
And in thy gaze, all shadows stray.  

The world may offer golden dreams,  
Sweet laughter, fleeting ecstasy,  
Yet I, content with simpler themes,  
Would trade them all for only thee.  

So let the seasons come and go,  
Let fortune rise or fall for me—  
My every joy, my every woe,  
Dear love, is nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Would I endure the restless night,  
Counting the hours until I see  
Your gentle smile, your eyes so bright.  

The world may offer gold and fame,  
Sweet promises that come and go,  
But all of them are but a name—  
A fleeting shadow, empty show.  

For in your arms I find my rest,  
A haven from the stormy sea;  
No treasure true, no rarest guest,  
Can hold my heart as you hold me.  

Let time and fate do as they will,  
My love remains, my hope is still,  
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,  
I’d brave the coldest winter’s night,  
I’d bear the storms upon the sea,  
And wander far from warmth and light.  

Your voice, a haven from despair,  
Your hand, a beacon through the gloom;  
No riches could persuade me where  
You are not waiting in the room.  

For every hope and every dream  
Is gathered gently in your gaze;  
The world’s bright treasures only seem  
A pale reflection of your blaze.  

So take my heart, it’s yours to keep—  
For nothing less than thee, I leap.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Do I awake with hope each day,  
The sun itself seems pale to me  
Beside the warmth you send my way.  

No fortune, fame, nor distant star,  
Could tempt my heart to ever roam;  
For in your arms, no matter far,  
I find my peace, my soul, my home.  

Let others seek what life may bring,  
In restless quests for what will be—  
My every wish, my every spring,  
Is rooted deep in loving thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,  
The world grows soft and still,  
A hush upon the trembling tree,  
A promise time cannot fulfill.  

I search the dusk for signs of you,  
In every shadow, every breeze;  
My heart recalls what once it knew—  
A longing only you appease.  

For kingdoms rise and kingdoms fall,  
And stars may falter in the sky,  
Yet I would trade the sum of all  
For just the light within your eye.  

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,  
My soul would cross eternity.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Do I awake each dawn anew:
The sun itself seems pale to me
Unless it shines upon our two.

The gentle wind that sweeps the hill,
The whispered hush of ancient trees,
All sing your name, and, sweeter still,
Bring solace on their honeyed breeze.

For every hope that stirs my heart,
And every dream that dares to be,
Springs forth because you are a part—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

So let the stars in midnight skies
Bear witness to this vow from me:
My soul, my song, my very sighs—
Are given, love, for none but thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender heart and mind.
The world may whisper endlessly,
But in your gaze, my truth I find.

For every star that graces night,
For every dawn’s uncertain gleam,
I chase the shadow, seek the light
That lingers softly in your dream.

No riches tempt, no laurel’s fame,
No fleeting pleasure calls to me;
A simple breath that speaks your name
Outshines the gold of destiny.

So let the seasons come and go,
And time erase what time must be;
My heart is steadfast, this I know:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
The rivers flow, the willows bend,
And in the hush of memory
My longing finds no other end.

The moon may rise, the tides may fall,
But still my spirit seeks your face;
For in your arms I have my all,
And every hurt you do erase.

Let kingdoms crumble, stars expire,
Let history’s pages turn to dust;
Yet in my soul, undimmed desire
Burns on with hope, with faith, with trust.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
I live, I dream, I dare, I be.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Does my heart dare to beat and sing.
No promise, fortune, nor decree
Could match the joy your presence brings.

Through storm and sun, through dusk and dawn,
My spirit journeys, ever true.
All worldly treasures pale and gone,
Compared to love I find in you.

Let others seek their fleeting bliss,
In shadows cast by vanity;
I crave no more than your sweet kiss—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Forevermore, my soul’s refrain
Is shaped by you, my destiny;
For only you dispel my pain,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
I’d cross the storm and silent sea;
No star above, nor rose in bloom,
Could fill my world or light my room.

Your voice, a balm to weary days,
Unfolds my heart in gentle ways.
Your laughter is the summer rain,
That washes doubt and soothes my pain.

The world may promise many things—
A golden crown, a nightingale’s wings—
But none enthrall or comfort me,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

So let the fates their courses run,
I’ll seek no moon, I’ll chase no sun;
All that I am, I give so free,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:

But hands entwined and spirits free—
For nothing less my soul would brave
The endless dark, for only thee.

Could lure my heart, nor tempt my eyes;
For all the world’s delights would pale
Beside the truth that you unveil.

Your laughter is my guiding star,
Your voice the music near or far.
In every breath, your name I find—
A whispered promise, intertwined.

Dear love, for nothing less than this,
I’d trade the world for one sweet kiss,
And wander time’s unending lea—
For nothing less, for only thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender dreams unspoken,

You are the dawn, the evening’s rest,
The gentle hush of twilight’s sigh;
No treasure, gold, nor silken crest,
Could ever bid this soul goodbye.

For you, I’d weather every storm,
And walk the path where sorrows lead;
Your name alone can keep me warm,
And in your gaze my spirit’s freed.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Is all my longing, all my plea.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I watch the seasons turn,
And feel the gentle mystery
Of lessons still to learn.

Your absence paints the evening blue,
Yet fills the day with song;
My every thought returns to you,
Where all my hopes belong.

No distant dream, no golden prize,
Could shift my steadfast heart;
For in your gaze, the whole world lies,
And I become a part.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could make me braver, true;
For all I am, or hope to be,
Is found in loving you.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could stir the world inside my chest,
Nor move the silent, rooted tree,
Nor grant my weary soul its rest.

For only you, the moonlight bends
To paint a path along the sea;
For only you, the morning sends
Its golden promise back to me.

No riches, glory, fleeting prize,
Could tempt these arms away from you;
In every dawn, your gentle eyes
Reveal a life made bright and true.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could shape the song I long to sing;
For only you, my spirit’s free—
For only you, my heart takes wing.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I trade the morning light,
Nor barter all the silver sea
For absence of thy sight.

The world could offer jeweled years,
Or promise kingdoms yet to be,
But none could wash away these fears,
Nor fill this heart’s deep plea.

For every hope, for every dream,
Is measured by the spark in you;
Your laughter is the sunbeam’s gleam,
Your sorrow paints my skies with blue.

So let the night be long and wild,
Let tempests roar across the lea—
I’d brave them all, both fate and trial,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender hope and pride;
No wealth nor fame could purchase me
A joy that stands so true beside.

The stars may fall, the sun may fade,
The seasons turn and rivers flee;
Yet in my heart, a promise laid—
I live for nothing less than thee.

Thy laughter paints the dullest days,
Thy voice redeems the darkest night.
The world’s acclaim, a fleeting haze;
Thy presence is my burning light.

So let the universe decree
Its fortunes and its destiny—
My soul remains, steadfast and free,
Bound, dear love, for naught but thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Could move my soul or set it free.
No diamond bright, nor golden crown,
Nor glory sung in every town,
Could stir the depths where longing sleeps,
Or wake the dream my spirit keeps.

The moon may rise, the stars may fall—
Yet you alone outshine them all.
For in your gaze, the world is new,
And hope restores its brightest hue.

Let time and tide their tempests send,
Let kingdoms fall and ages end;
Still in my heart, one truth will be:
Dear love, there’s nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I forsake the dawn’s embrace,
Nor trade the quiet constancy
That lives within your gentle face.

No distant sun, no fabled star,
Could draw my longing gaze away;
For all the wonders near and far
Fade in the light of your day.

Let others seek their fleeting gold,
Or chase the wind across the sea;
I know the treasure that I hold:
Dear love, there’s nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I outwait the cruelest storm,
Or cross the night’s uncertainty
For just the memory of your form.

No price could weigh the worth I find
In every word and every glance,
Nor time erase the ties that bind
My soul to yours in silent dance.

The world may turn, the seasons flee,
And all that’s certain may decay—
Still, in my heart, eternally,
Dear love, for thee I choose to stay.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
The stars would pale and shadows flee—
The gentle hush of twilight’s sigh
Would hold its breath as you pass by.

No songbird’s verse, no ocean’s sweep,
Can match the solace that I keep
Within your gaze, where worlds unfold,
And silent dreams are softly told.

For you, the rose delays its bloom;
The moonlight lingers in my room.
Every heartbeat, every plea—
Is whispered thus: for none but thee.

So take these words, a humble plea:
My heart beats on for naught but thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
The sun would rise in vain for me,
For all the world’s resplendent light
Is dimmed without your spirit bright.

No riches, power, nor fleeting fame
Could warm my soul or fan the flame
That only you, with gentle art,
Ignite within my faithful heart.

The winding road, the restless sea,
Mean little if you’re not with me.
So here I wait, both calm and free,
For nothing less—no, nothing less—than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
I’d cross the winter’s deepest sea,
Brave tempests wild, and mountains high,
To find the solace of your sigh.

No gold or jewel, nor silken thread,
Could tempt me from the path we tread;
For in your eyes, my world begins,
And in your arms, my solace ends.

Let kingdoms fall and empires fade,
Let time itself its ransom trade—
Yet steadfast, I shall always be,
Content with nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I forsake eternity.
The turning stars, the restless sky
Are pale when you are drawing nigh.

No sweeter gift the fates could send
Than your soft hand, my love, my friend.
In every dawn, in every night,
My soul finds home within your light.

Though seasons pass and years may flee,
My heart belongs to none but thee.
So let the world in shadow be—
I ask, dear love, for only thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I renounce the world, the sea,
The mountains high, the valleys deep—
For you alone, my vows I keep.

The morning dew, the crimson rose,
Are dim compared to what I chose:
A heart devoted, tried and true,
That beats in time with thoughts of you.

No fleeting pleasure, gold or fame,
Could ever kindle such a flame.
So here I stand, my soul set free—
For nothing less, dear love, than thee.

responses.text:

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

So let the seasons come and go,
Let time’s great river carry me,
I’ll hold to that which I best know:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I traverse the storm-tossed night,
Or scale the peaks of agony,
For in thy gaze, I find my light.

No riches, fame, nor fleeting praise
Could ever tempt this heart from you;
Thy voice, thy touch, thy gentle ways
Are treasures deep and ever true.

Should all the world turn cold and gray,
And hope grow faint as distant sea,
Still would I rise and find my way,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender dreams or sleep,
Or cross the wild and restless sea,
Where shadows fall and waters weep.

For in your eyes, the morning breaks,
A dawn that bids all sorrow cease;
In every vow my spirit makes,
I find your promise and my peace.

No distant star, no golden prize,
Could lure my heart away from you;
Dear love, for nothing less than ties
That bind us strong and ever true.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I forsake the world entire:
The emerald fields, the ancient tree,
The hearth’s familiar fire.

No crown, no coin, nor poet’s fame
Could tempt my soul to turn and flee
The gentle music of thy name—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

So let the night grow dark and deep,
And tempests shake the trembling lea,
Still I am thine, awake or sleep,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I endure the longest night,
Or trade the sun’s own liberty

The world may sing in silver tones,

So let the tempests rise and fall,
Let fortune’s winds be wild and free;
I ask no more, I seek no thrall,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer, the air shimmered bright,
Golden rays danced down in a cascade of light.
The meadows lay hushed in a languorous swoon,
As cicadas sang hymns to the drowsy, warm noon.

The river, a ribbon of silvery gleam,
Mirrored the sky in a sun-spangled dream.
Shadowless trees stood in emerald repose,
Their leaves whisper-quiet, their branches morose.

Petals unfurled in the languid embrace
Of sunlight that cherished each delicate face.
A butterfly drifted on currents of heat,
While grasses bowed low in the summer’s defeat.

No sound but the longing of bees on the wing,
And distant bells hinting of something to sing.
'Twas noontide of summer, a moment so still—
The world holding breath on a sun-burnished hill.

'Twas noontide of summer, the fields all aglow,
Every blade of green grass basked in the slow
Languid drift of the sun, painting shadows so slight
That even the songbirds grew quiet in light.

The river ran lazy, its surface a glaze
Of glimmer and shimmer in midsummer’s haze.
Children’s faint laughter, now distant and low,
Carried through air heavy, fragrant and slow.

The wildflowers nodded, their petals asleep,
While dragonflies hovered and willows would weep.
The world seemed to drowse in the arms of the heat,
Dreaming of rainstorms and cool evening’s treat.

'Twas noontide of summer, when time seems to pause,
Each moment suspended by nature’s own laws.
A day wrapped in sunlight, a slumbering spell—
The heart of the season, remembered so well.

'Twas noontide of summer, the sky a bold blue,
When everything shimmered in luminous hue.
The daisies stood tall, in the thick of the field,
While the sun’s golden fingers to earth gently kneeled.

A breeze barely stirred the lush, ripening grain,
And the swallows soared high, on invisible lanes.
The orchards grew heavy with promise and peace,
And the world seemed to hold its warm breath with ease.

'Twas a moment suspended, where time gently lay,
On the wings of the noon, in the heart of the day.
From the hum of the bees to the cool shade of trees,
Summer’s sweet noontide brought solace and ease.

So pause in this sunlight, let worries depart,
And carry the warmth of this hour in your heart.

'Twas noontide of summer, the world at its peak,
The sunlight relentless, the shadows grown weak.
A chorus of crickets sang out from the grass,
While dragonflies flit like green shards of glass.

The old oaks stood watchful, their branches stretched wide,
Offering shade where the wild deer could hide.
Not a cloud marred the blue, not a wind bent the trees,
Just the hush of the warm, heavy, honey-thick breeze.

Somewhere a brook whispered, half-hidden from view,
Telling secrets to stones as the sunlight slipped through.
The roses drooped low in the garden’s embrace,
Their perfume a memory the air could not trace.

'Twas noontide of summer—a pause in the day,
Where all of the world seemed to drift far away.

'Twas noontide of summer, and languid the air,
With golden sunbeams weaving warmth everywhere.
The fields lay in silence, the wildflowers bowed,
While locusts sang softly, a delicate shroud.

The river moved slowly, a silver-backed snake,
Meandering past willows that dozed in its wake.
No breeze stirred the branches, no leaf dared to fall,
As heat pressed its palm on the world, over all.

In the hush of that hour, time’s pulse seemed to slow,
And dreams wandered lazy, wherever they’d go.
A hush on the meadow, a spell on the trees—
'Twas noontide of summer, and peace on the breeze.

Let memory linger where sunlight was deep,
And carry the stillness through waking and sleep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
War's a joke for me and you,
A tale spun in the morning dew.
We laugh at what our fathers knew,
The trenches, blood, the smoky blue.

We trade in memes and clever lines,
While headlines scroll and hope declines.
Our coffee cools, the world unwinds—
We jest, distracted, by design.

Yet somewhere distant, shells still fall,
A distant thunder, none recall.
We joke, we tweet, we stand so tall,
As if the war would never call.

But laughter’s thin, the punchline cruel.
War’s a joke for me and you—
Until the day the joke breaks through,
And we find it’s laughing too.

War's a joke for me and you—
A game played on a distant field,
Where stories told of valor grew,
And ancient wounds are slow to heal.

We sip our drinks and trade our quips,
Safe from the echoes in the sand,
Oblivious to trembling lips
That hold a fate we can't withstand.

We laugh, we jest, we keep our peace,
Pretending all the pain is gone,
But somewhere, battles never cease,
And daylight dies before the dawn.

War’s a joke, we say and smile,
But in the shadows, sorrow grew—
For war is real, and all the while,
It’s laughing at me and you.

War's a joke for me and you,
Or so we say, behind a screen,
Removed from mud, removed from hue
Of blood and smoke and things unseen.

We jest about the distant fight,
As if the bombs are far removed,
As if the cost is out of sight,
A burden others must have proved.

We laugh at what we do not know,
At uniforms and marching feet,
At stories told from long ago
When hope and terror used to meet.

But war, unjoking, waits its turn—
A shadow on the evening news—
And all the while, we never learn
How war is nothing left to lose.

War's a joke for me and you,
A jest exchanged with morning tea,
Our laughter shields us from the view
Of others' harsh reality.

We watch it flicker on the screen,
A drama spun for our delight,
While men and women, caught between
The lines, know only fear and night.

His madness, a mirror, reflecting me,

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—

His laughter cracks the silence, raw and bright,

I do not flinch beneath his savage gaze,

He looks at me, and I cannot disguise

Haunted by memories he cannot name.

The quiet moments, small, divine,
That whisper, "You are always here."

A melody that will not cease:

That grants the weary spirit peace.

Blessed be Thou for every grace,

For every gift, both great and small,

Blessed be Thou for all the joy.

For dreams that flutter, soft and new,

With every breath, my soul will sing,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'lonely'

responses.text:
Lonely, like a single leaf in fall,
Drifting softly, answering no call,
Its golden veins a map of silent roads,
Borne gently on the wind that never slows.

Lonely, like a window lit at night,

Yet inside, only shadows roam and rest,
Longing for a heartbeat, for a guest.

Lonely, yet the stars still dare to burn,
Each a distant soul who waits their turn,
To whisper hope upon the quiet air,
A promise that another will be there.

And so, in gentle solitude I lie,
Not broken, but learning how to fly,
For loneliness, though cold and vast and wide,
Can be the place where dreams and hearts reside.

Lonely is the echo in an empty room,
Footsteps fading softly into gloom.
A single chair by the window’s edge,
Catches sunlight—a silent pledge.

Lonely is the song the robin sings
When spring forgets to spread its wings.
The hush of dusk, the sigh of trees,
A longing carried on the breeze.

Yet in this quiet, seeds take root,
The heart finds solace, tender, mute.
Lonely, yes, but not undone—
A hope, a promise, just begun.

Lonely was the hour the sun withdrew,
Casting shadows long and blue,
Where silence draped the walls in gray,
And laughter faded far away.

Lonely is the river’s mournful tune,
Underneath a waning moon,
It sings of hearts that drift apart,
Of empty hands and aching hearts.

Yet in this space where echoes grow,
New light begins to softly show.
Lonely is a season, brief—
A passage through the ache of grief.

Lonely, a word that drifts on the wind,
A single feather with nowhere to land,
It circles the quiet inside of my chest,
A gentle ache that will not rest.

Lonely, a shadow across the floor,
Stretching farther with each closing door.
Yet in the hush, a fragile bloom—
A hope that breaks the endless gloom.

Lonely, and yet the stars still shine,
A silent promise in their design,
That somewhere, someone feels this too—
And dreams of finding something true.

Lonely, like a song with no refrain,
A memory lost in falling rain,
It weaves between the silent halls,
And lingers gently on the walls.

Lonely, the echo of a name,
Spoken once, now not the same,
A longing for a touch or word,
A comfort barely seen or heard.

But in the hush of empty hours,
A seed of hope begins to flower,
For even in the deepest night,
The dawn will come to bring its light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text:
Upon the dawn, the silence broke—
Not gentle words, nor olive cloak,
But through the mist, a shadow poured:
On the scene came Christ The Lord.

Not with peace, nor whispered word,
But iron bright, a burning sword.
He cleaved the night, divided dreams,
Unraveled old familiar seams.

His sandals thundered on the ground,
A challenge in the trumpet’s sound.
He called the hearts to stand or flee—
No comfort left in certainty.

For love may wound before it heals,
Truth uncovers what it steals.
And in the light of judgment’s day,
The sword will carve the narrow way.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword,
Dividing night from hopeful dawn,
Things once hidden, now withdrawn.

His words, like fire, cut the air,
Truth and mercy, laid bare,
He summoned courage, banished lies,
Unveiling hearts, exposing ties.

He called not for the quiet life,
But for the end of inward strife;
To stand, to choose, to walk the line,
Between the mortal and divine.

So tremble not when thunder sounds,
Or when the world comes crashing down;
For in the clash of love and war,
He stands victorious evermore.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Lightning flashed and thunder roared,
Ancient walls of comfort floored.

No gentle hand, no easy way,
But truth that burns the chaff away.
He called the meek, the lost, the shamed,
And in their hearts a fire was named.

A sword to sever false from real,
To challenge what we dare not feel.
He did not promise peace on earth,
But offered each a second birth.

So let the blade of justice gleam,
And cut through every broken dream.
For in the clash of night and day,
His sword of love will light the way.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword;
A whisper shattered by the blade,
A truth no gentle hand could trade.

He swept through crowds with burning eyes,
Unveiling wounds and hidden lies.
Not to comfort, not to bind,
But to split the soul and mind.

He called to those who hid in shade,
To step into the light, unafraid.
His sword would sever, not console,
But cleanse the spirit, heal the soul.

So now I see the path He made:
A narrow road, but not afraid.
For with the sword, He showed the way—
To break the chains, and not to stay.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
His voice rang sharp across the land,
Dividing soul and spirit, hand from hand.

He called the weary to awake,
Demanded truth for mercy's sake.
His mission, veiled in paradox,
Split the stone, unbarred the locks.

No gentle dove, no quiet plea,
But fire and steel and destiny.
He sought not calm, but hearts aflame,
To bear the sword and speak His name.

So in the clash of light and dark,
His coming leaves a holy mark.
Not peace, but purpose fierce and bright—
A sword against the endless night.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.

His sword was truth, his shield was grace,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
Everyone has a fear, tucked beneath the bone—
A shadow in the hallway, a chill when we’re alone.
It whispers in the morning, it lingers in the night,
A shape behind the curtain, just out of sight.

Some fear the silence, others the storm,
A future uncertain, hearts weather-worn.
We hide it in laughter, we mask it in cheer,
But quietly, always, everyone has a fear.

Yet fear is a lantern, a flicker in the gloom,
A promise that courage can also bloom.
So hold close your worries, acknowledge the tear—
Bravery’s born because everyone has a fear.

Everyone has a fear, a shadow cast long and deep,
It lingers in the silence, it surfaces in sleep.
Some hide it well behind a smile, others let it show,
It tugs behind our footsteps, wherever we may go.

A word left unspoken, a door left untried,
A longing for safety, a need to confide.
Yet within this trembling, within every tear,
We find we're together—everyone has a fear.

So let us be gentle, patient, and kind,
For battles are raging in many a mind.
In facing our darkness, in holding it near,
We find we are human, and everyone has a fear.

Everyone has a fear, a secret well concealed,
A trembling at the threshold, a wound that’s never healed.
It’s woven through our stories, it colors every dream,
It’s softer than a whisper, it’s louder than a scream.

Some fear the loss of love, some fear the passing days,
Some dread the unknown road, or fortune’s fickle ways.
Yet in our silent trembling, a quiet strength appears—
The courage to keep moving, despite our hidden fears.

For fear is not a weakness, but something we all bear,
A thread within the tapestry that makes us truly care.

Everyone has a fear, a trembling in the chest,
A moment of uncertainty that never comes to rest.
It might be heights or loneliness, or simply growing old,
A shadow in the corner, a story left untold.

We dance with our anxieties, we cradle them at night,
Sometimes they shrink away, sometimes they bite.
But in the hush between heartbeats, courage can appear—
A quiet revolution: facing every fear.

So let us walk together, in honesty and grace,
Knowing fear is universal, a challenge we all face.

Everyone has a fear, silent as the dawn,
A gentle ache of longing, a worry never gone.
It hides behind our laughter, it sleeps beneath our skin,
A secret kept in darkness, a battle fought within.

We fear the unknown ending, we fear what we might lose,
We fear to love too deeply, afraid of every bruise.
But fear, when faced together, grows smaller day by day—
A lesson in compassion, as we stumble on our way.

Embrace your trembling shadow, let kindness draw it near,
For we are not alone here—everyone has a fear.

A flower in the darkness, that only the brave one knows.

A universal language, where all have walked and been.

A trembling thought in the morning, a shadow that will not flee.
A hush in a crowded room, a chill on a sleepless night,

Some carry it in silence, some sing it in a song,

But fear is a common language, spoken by every heart,
A thread that binds our differences, a place for hope to start.

So let us greet our fears gently, and honor those we see,
For everyone has a fear—yet still, we choose to be.
We walk together, trembling, toward what we hope is true,
With courage as our lantern, and kindness leading through.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
In quiet dawn, my soul intones  
A song of yearning, truth revealed,  
A heart unguarded, gently healed.  

While stars dissolve and night is flown,  
Thy presence, steadfast, guides my own;  
Upon the heights, in shadowed vale,  
Thy mercy, endless, will not fail.  

No idol draws my gaze aside,  
No fleeting hope, no empty pride;  
Thou art the wellspring, deep and clear,  
The voice that tells me, “I am near.”  

In desert thirst, in surging tide,  
Thy love and faithfulness abide.  
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
In thee, my soul finds rest—my home.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
Amidst the world’s relentless tide,  
Thy gentle hand has drawn me home  
When all around, the lights have died.  

No other voice can calm my fear,  
No other touch can heal my pain,  
In silent awe, I sense Thee near,  
A constant presence, sweet refrain.  

Through shadowed valleys, mountain high,  
Thy mercy is my guiding star;  
O God, my soul to Thee will fly,  
No distance ever felt too far.  

Thou art my dawn, my hope, my song,  
With every breath, to Thee I cling;  
O God! Thou art my God alone—  
My heart, my life, my offering.

O God! Thou art my God alone;

O God! Thou art my God alone;

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind life and remember, gentle as dawn’s first light—  
Soft echoes drift through autumn air,  
Footsteps on golden leaves, laughter in the fading night,  
Memories threaded with both joy and care.  

A childhood’s echo, a lover’s glance,  
Moments like rain on window glass—  
Time’s river flows, but in a trance  
We gather fragments that will pass.  

In silent rooms, old photographs gleam,  
Stories whisper behind each frame,  
Rewind life and remember the dream—  
No two days are ever the same.  

So cradle the past in a gentle hand,  
Let memory’s lantern softly burn,  
For hearts can heal and understand,  
When we rewind life and return.

Rewind life and remember—  
The laughter ringing down silent halls,  
The warmth of summer’s gentle ember,  
Childhood’s canvas on old brick walls.  

Pages flutter in the winds of time,  
Faces flicker in golden haze,  
Moments, sweet and sometimes sublime,  
Lost in the tangle of forgotten days.  

Pause with me, let’s walk the years,  
Trace the lines of joy and sorrow,  
Hold close the smiles, the whispered cheers,  
And hope for more tomorrows.  

Rewind life and remember,  
For in memory’s tender keep,  
We find the heart’s true ember,  
Alive in dreams and deep.

Rewind life and remember—  
The gentle hush before the storm,  
The scent of rain on thirsty earth,  
A mother’s voice, a promise warm.  

The world spun bright with innocence,  
A thousand days in golden hue,  
Time slipped by, a fleeting dance,  
But memories remain true.  

Rewind life and remember—  
Not to dwell or mourn the flight,  
But to cradle every ember  
That gave the darkness light.  

May we wander through tomorrow  
With the wisdom yesterday sends,  
Carrying hope, joy, and sorrow—  
Rewind life, and make amends.

Rewind life and remember—  
Moments caught in sepia tones,  
Old laughter echoing, soft and tender,  
Shadows flicker where sunlight shone.  

Hands held tight in distant seasons,  
Promises etched in the dusk,  
Silent tears and secret reasons,  
Time’s perfume, bittersweet musk.  

Turn the reel of memory slow,  
Relive the stories, frame by frame,  
Let the gentle current flow,  
Calling each forgotten name.  

Rewind life and remember,  
Every joy and gentle ache;  
For the heart, in its ember,  
Finds the love it cannot fake.

Rewind life and remember—  
The soft sigh of yesterday’s breeze,  
Footprints pressed in silver sand,  
Whispers carried by ancient trees.  

Distant laughter, a fleeting song,  
The hush of a midnight prayer,  
Fragments of where we once belonged,  
Tender moments beyond compare.  

As we retrace the winding years,  
Turning pages worn and thin,  
We gather both the joy and tears,  
Letting memory’s river begin.  

Rewind life and remember—  
Not to undo what’s been done,  
But to cherish each glowing ember  
As another new day is begun.

The world softens, warm and tender—
So close your eyes and, just because,
Rewind life and remember.

Rewind life and remember
The gentle weight of time,
How every day, like falling leaves,
Is precious and sublime.

Recall the laughter echoing
In rooms of faded light,
The quiet dreams we harbored
On long and restless nights.

Rewind life and remember
Each promise and regret,
The faces lost to distance,
The love we can’t forget.

For memory is a compass
Through all that’s come and gone.
Rewind life and remember—
And let the heart move on.

Rewind life and remember,
The gentle hush of yesteryear,
A songbird’s call at morning light,
A whispered wish, a vanished fear.

Turn back the dial, let moments play,
Soft sepia tones of olden days.
Catch laughter fleeting, faces bright,
Lost voices echo in the haze.

Rewind life and remember—
Each heartbeat set in amber glow.
The dreams we chased, the tears we wept,
The places only we could know.

For time may press forever forward,
But memory can always bend;
Rewind life and remember—
The stories that don’t end.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind life and remember,
A sepia film in the mind’s old projector,
Moments flicker – laughter, tears,
A chorus of forgotten years.

Childhood’s sun on blinking skin,
The echo of a distant hymn,

The scent of rain on summer streets,

Rewind life and remember –

Rewind life and remember

Rewind life and remember

Rewind life and remember

Rewind life and remember

Rewind life and remember

Rewind life and remember
The laughter echoing through the halls,

Gathering fragments: a smile, a song,
A whispered promise in the dark.

If only I could press pause,
Relive the gentle touch of a friend,
The thrill of a first adventure,
The comfort of familiar places.

But memory is its own miracle,

Rewind life and remember,

In the mirror of memory’s chamber,

Rewind life and remember,

Rewind life and remember:

The scent of rain on dusty streets,

Rewind life and remember:
How laughter danced on summer air,
How dreams once seemed so close, so bright,
And hope was everywhere.

But time, relentless, moves ahead,

Yet in our hearts, those memories live,

So pause, rewind, and let them play—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Curved spine scraping the cold stone floors,
My voice a whisper, my dreams mere grunts,
Clawing shadows behind locked doors.

The world loomed tall and I, so small,
Bent beneath burdens I dared not name,
Hoping for crumbs from banquet halls,
Ashamed of hungers I could not tame.

But morning found me, golden and new,
Sunrise anointing my battered skin.
From humbled roots, resilience grew—
A trembling leaf, a restless wind.

Now I rise, unshackled and free,
No longer crawling, but learning to soar.
Once a grovelling creature—now me:
Standing tall where I knelt before.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Curled tight in the shell of my fear,
Eyes fixed on the mud, voice lost in the dust,
Crawling through each desperate year.

But somewhere, a dawning—a flicker of light—
Crept into my trembling heart,
And the weight of the world, for one fleeting night,
Fell away as I dared to restart.

Now I walk with a steadier tread,
No longer chained to the ground;
I lift my face to the sunrise ahead,
And listen for hope’s quiet sound.

For though I was a grovelling creature once,
I have learned to stand and to see:
The journey from earth to the sky is the dance
Of becoming the best of me.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Crushed beneath the heel of days,
My bones bent to the whim of want,
My voice a broken phrase.

The world above, so sharp and bright,
Was hidden by the mud and stone,
And I, more shadow than of light,
Forgot the shape of home.

Yet in the smallest crack of night,
A single blade of green broke through—
And in its stubborn, slender fight,
A promise gently grew.

I rose, not all at once, but slow,
Each inch a victory claimed,
And where the grovelling roots once drove,
Now stands a soul reclaimed.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bound to the earth by silent chains,
My spirit dim, my courage dunce,
My hands collecting only pains.

I licked the dust of others’ pride,
Afraid to speak, to dream, to dance,
But in the hollow where I’d hide
A seed of longing found its chance.

The moon would whisper to my skin
Of worlds where grovelling had no place;
Her silver light would seep within,
And coax my heart to join the race.

Now, though my knees remember still
The weight that kept me pressed and low,
I stand, defiant, on this hill:
A creature risen from below.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Clinging to scraps of hope in the dark,
My humble wishes drowned in silence,
My spirit lost its spark.

I crept through days on trembling limbs,
The world a mountain, steep and bare,
Afraid to lift my heavy chin,
Afraid of what was there.

Yet even grovelling creatures dream,
And so I dreamed of open skies,
Of standing tall beside a stream,
Of laughter in my eyes.

With slow resolve and gentle hands,
I brushed the dirt away,
And though I still recall the sands,
I’ve found my light today.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:

No longer crawling in the dust,

I was a grovelling creature once,

I watched the world through lowered eyes,

Now memory serves a gentle sting—

I was a grovelling creature once,

But time is kind to those who yearn,

From crawling, slowly, I discern

Now I am different, changed by years,

I was a grovelling creature once,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy, so the world spins slow,
Laughter curling like smoke in the late afternoon—
Sunlight on faces, a gentle yellow glow
Warming the pavement and the promise of June.

Children are skipping, their voices in flight,
Elderly neighbors wave from their stoops,
The market is humming, bananas pile bright,
A kettle whistles, and a sparrow swoops.

People are happy, and joy finds its way
Into small gestures, in coffee and bread,
Unwritten stories unfolding each day,
A thousand soft moments, nothing to dread.

If only this feeling could always remain—
People are happy, and so is the rain.

People are happy, or so it may seem,
Wandering sidewalks, lost in a dream.
Smiles like lanterns flicker on cheeks,
Words like honey, sweet when they speak.

People are happy, the afternoon glows,
Children are running, the garden still grows.
Laughter and music drift on the breeze,
Hearts a bit lighter, minds more at ease.

Yet underneath laughter, a shadow may stir,
A longing unspoken, a memory blur.
Still, in this moment, let’s savor the song,
People are happy, the world moves along.

People are happy, the air feels so light,
Laughter like raindrops sparkling and bright.
Windows wide open, the city in bloom,
Hope finds a home in each sun-dappled room.

Sidewalks are humming with footsteps and cheer,
Old friends embracing, new faces appear.
Sparrows are singing, the sky stretches blue,
Dreams gently rising, impossible too.

People are happy, hearts open and wide,
Sharing their stories with nothing to hide.
For a moment, the world lets its worries fall free—
People are happy, and so, we will be.

People are happy, or so I'm told,
Their laughter like sunlight, their stories like gold.
They dance through the mornings, they sing in the rain,
Their worries are feathers, too light to be pain.

People are happy, the world is aglow,
Petals unfolding wherever they go.
But look a bit closer, don’t trust every grin—
Sometimes joy sparkles to cover what’s within.

Still, in the daylight, let’s join in the play,
Let smiles be bridges, if just for today.
People are happy, and maybe that’s true—
For a moment, let happiness find me and you.

People are happy, the morning is bright,
Sunbeams are dancing on faces in light.
Chatter and laughter fill corners and streets,
Echoes of kindness in every heartbeat.

People are happy, in gardens and parks,
Children are drawing with sidewalk chalk marks.
Old friends are meeting with hugs and with tea,
Hope like a songbird, alive in the tree.

People are happy, and maybe it’s clear—
Sometimes joy lingers, and sorrow draws near.
But here in this moment, the world feels at peace,
People are happy, and worries release.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Blanketing hills in a silent white cover.
Trees bowed low beneath its weight,
Roads vanished, erased by fate.

Windows glowed with candlelight,
Inside, warmth defied the night.
Every field, every lane,
Dissolved beneath a crystal plain.

Children’s laughter, muffled and sweet,
Bootprints lost in a soft retreat.
All was quiet, gentle, slow—
A world remade in drifting snow.

Hope and hush in the falling flakes,
A promise whispered as morning breaks:
That beneath this shroud, pure and deep,
The world, in silence, dares to sleep.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A hush descended, soft as a lover’s cover.
Mountains vanished beneath white veils,
Oceans stilled, and icy gales
Whispered secrets through frozen air,
Weaving silence everywhere.

City lights flickered, blurred by the storm,
Children’s laughter a fleeting form.
No border remained, no line to be drawn—
Just endless white from dusk to dawn.

Beneath that cloak, the tired earth lay,
Dreaming of spring, far away.
Until the thaw, all life would sleep,
Cradled in snow, silence deep.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A blanket woven from cloud and clover.
Rooftops disappeared, trees wore lace,
Time itself seemed to slow its pace.

Footsteps vanished, pathways gone,
The hush of winter lingered on.
Birds took shelter, rivers froze,
Petals hidden beneath the snows.

Yet in the quiet, hearts grew bold,
Stories whispered, hands to hold.
The world, transformed in dazzling white,
Glimmered softly through the night.

It snowed and snowed, no end in sight,
The earth at peace, bathed in light.
Dreams drifted gently, far and wide,
Snowflakes falling, side by side.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Turning cities to fields of clover.
Every rooftop, every street,
Lost beneath a white retreat.

The air grew still, the sky hung low,
Each breath a cloud, each step slow.
No bird nor beast, no voice nor cry—
Just endless flakes from a silver sky.

Children pressed faces to frosted glass,
Watching the silent hours pass.
The globe, for once, in unity lay,
Softened, stilled, beneath the gray.

It snowed and snowed, and in that hush,
The world remembered how to blush,
And dream anew in winter’s hold,
A story spun in silent cold.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Erasing footprints, fields, and clover.
The sky was heavy, silent, slate,
As flakes fell slow, deliberate, late.

Villages vanished, rivers hushed,
The world in ivory quiet, brushed.
No borders, boundaries, fences seen,
Just endless, gleaming winter sheen.

Children’s laughter, muffled, bright,
Lit the twilight, warmed the night.
Beneath the shroud, the earth lay deep,
Cradled softly, lulled to sleep.

It snowed and snowed, a dream retold,
A gentle spell the world would hold,
Till dawn would break, and light would show
Life stirring beneath the snow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy, the world unfolds—
A paper crane in gentle hands,
Sunlight stitching gold on the windowsill,
Laughter like rain on thirsty lands.

When I am happy, colors bloom
Where once the shadows dared to live,
And every breath, a sweet perfume,
Is something I am glad to give.

The sky wears blue like a favorite song,
Clouds slip by with weightless ease;
Hope is a bird that sings along,
Carried high on a summer breeze.

When I am happy, I remember this:
Joy is not always loud or bright—
Sometimes it’s a quiet kiss,
A whispered promise in the night.

When I am happy, the morning sings,
Soft gold resting on feathered wings.
The air is crisp, and laughter flows,
A gentle river that only grows.

When I am happy, troubles seem small,
Like distant echoes in an endless hall.
My heart, unburdened, soars above,
Buoyed by gratitude, faith, and love.

When I am happy, colors ignite,
Petals unfurl in the warming light.
Moments are sweet, each second new,
The world a canvas of vibrant hue.

When I am happy, I wish to share
This fleeting joy, this breath of air—
For happiness, once set free,
Returns in echoes back to me.

When I am happy, I become the breeze—
Invisible hands stirring the leaves,
Unraveling laughter in quiet rooms,
Weaving sunlight through silver looms.

When I am happy, time slows down,
A gentle hush, a radiant crown,
Worries dissolve in morning dew,
And every hour feels bright and new.

When I am happy, I remember how
Simple things can lift the brow:
A sparrow’s song, a friend’s embrace,
Soft green grass, a peaceful place.

When I am happy, I close my eyes
And let my spirit gently rise—
Grateful for the fleeting day,
For happiness that lights the way.

When I am happy, the world is wide—
Fields of wonder on every side.
A secret smile, a whispered tune,
A heart that dances with the moon.

When I am happy, my worries fade,
Soft as the light on the edge of shade.
The air feels sweet, the colors sing,
And hope takes flight on gentle wing.

When I am happy, I want to stay
Within this golden, endless day.
To savor joy, to laugh, to run,
Beneath the sky, beneath the sun.

When I am happy, I remember you—
And happiness is doubled, too.
For joy, when shared, will always grow,
Like sunlight melting winter’s snow.

When I am happy, laughter spills—
Like water tumbling down the hill.
The air feels fresh, the sky expands,
Joy settles lightly in my hands.

When I am happy, music plays
In silent rooms, and ordinary days
Are painted gold with secret light,
Transforming worries into flight.

When I am happy, memories gleam
With the brightness of a waking dream.
I find old songs within my chest,
A private warmth, a quiet rest.

When I am happy, I remember
To gather moments, sweet and tender,
And hold them gently, like a prayer—
A promise that happiness is always there.

I saw an old cottage of clay,

Sunlight filtered through shattered glass,

The silence was deep as the hours would pass,

Yet the cottage stood firm in the field,
Rooted to earth and to stone,
With secrets and stories it never revealed,
But somehow I felt not alone.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A fragment of lives gone before.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

responses.text:
Loss can be good for us,
A teacher beneath sorrow’s skin;
It cracks the shell encasing us,
Lets softer light seep in.

We gather all we had, then mourn,
The empty spaces, aching wide.
But absence shapes a different form—
A strength that grows inside.

We learn the weight of letting go,
Of trusting roots unseen,
Of finding hope in what we sow,
Where memory has been.

So let the losses come and teach,
Though bitter as they start;
Their lessons, gentle, sometimes reach
The furthest corners of the heart.

Loss can be good for us,
Though it stings and leaves us bare.
In the hush that follows absence,
We find new ways to care.

Old dreams may fall like autumn leaves,
But space is made for growth.
In letting go, the soul retrieves
The courage to betroth

Itself to all that’s yet to come,
To hope where pain has been.
Loss carves a channel, beckoning
The healing light within.

So grieve, but let the lessons rise:
We gain, too, from goodbyes.

Loss can be good for us—
A paradox wrapped in pain,
A season of emptiness
That nourishes new terrain.

It humbles the proudest heart,
Teaches us how to bend,
Shows the cracks where sunlight starts,
And where healing can begin.

Though sorrow may cloud our days,
And tears may freely flow,
Loss whispers in quiet ways
Of all we’re meant to know.

In emptiness, we find room
For hope to gently bloom.

Loss can be good for us—
Though at first it breaks apart
The fragile scaffolds we have built
Inside a trusting heart.

It empties hands of certainty,
Leaves echoes in the night,
But in the silence, quietly
It opens up new sight.

What once we held so tightly,
We now can let release;
In absence there is mightily
A strange and stubborn peace.

With every loss, a lesson,
With every end, a start—
Loss can be good for us,
When we listen with the heart.

Loss can be good for us,
A hidden, bitter seed.
It cracks the shell of comfort,
To plant a deeper need.

It strips the branches bare,
But roots grow strong below.
In emptiness, we’re more aware
Of what we didn’t know.

Sorrow carves a hollow,
Where gentler things can grow.
It teaches us to follow
What only hearts can know.

So let the losses come,
Let tears and silence fall—
Loss can be good for us,
If we rise from it, at all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You scold the curtains, chase the dreams away.
Your golden fingers pry at slumbered eyes,
Demanding tribute at the break of day.

You do not heed the lovers’ silent plea,
Nor care for secrets whispered in the night—
Relentless, you unravel reveries,
Draping our chambers in intrusive light.

Yet, in your stubborn, gleaming reign above,
We find the pulse of time, the world’s embrace.
You paint the roofs with gold, the fields with love,
And draw the lines of laughter on each face.

So rage and rouse us, Sun, if you must do—
For every waking hour begins with you.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you prod and pry?
Your golden fingers tap the glass

You scatter shadows on the wall,
You spill across the floor.
You chase away the gentle night,
Demanding I ignore

The whispered dreams, the hush of love,
The comfort of the gloom.
You blare your trumpet through the clouds,
You barge into my room.

Yet, as you climb the painted sky,
I cannot stay your run;
Though I may grumble at your glare,
I wake to you, old Sun.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You fling your light through window cracks,
Disturbing dreams not yet begun,
Unraveling the velvet black.

With stubborn rays you prod and pry,
Breaking the hush of night with gold.
You chase the secrets from the sky,
Too brash, too bright, too uncontrolled.

Yet in your haste to rule the day,
You rouse the world from drowsy rest;
And though we beg you turn away,
You blaze ahead, a tireless guest.

Perhaps we grumble at your call,
But life would pale without your run.
So shine, and let your radiance fall,
You busy fool, unruly Sun.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You burst the hush of dawn with light,
You scatter shadows one by one,
And chase away the gentle night.

Why must you prod and peer so soon,
Demanding tribute from the bed?
We barter dreams beneath the moon,
But you would have our sleep instead.

Your golden hands tap windowpanes,
Impatient, restless, never still.
You turn the sky to glowing lanes,
Insistent on your ancient will.

Yet, for your folly, all forgive—
You stir the world and bid it live.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why do you rise so quick, so bright?
You scatter dreams and make us run,
Chasing away the velvet night.

You barge through curtains, bold and brash,
You wake the world with golden cries.
You turn our sleep to morning ash,
With laughter burning in the skies.

Have you no grace for lovers’ rest,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

responses.text:
We meet many people in life—
Some drift softly, like leaves on a breeze,
A brief hello, a gentle smile, a fleeting moment
Before their paths diverge from ours.

Some linger, like the scent of rain on summer grass,
Their laughter echoing in our halls,
Their kindness stitched into the fabric of our days,
Reminders in quiet hours that we are not alone.

Others arrive with thunder—
Storms that shake foundations, break and rebuild,
Teaching lessons we never sought,
Leaving behind cracked earth and blooming wildflowers.

We meet many people in life—
Each a star in our midnight sky,
Some burning bright, some fading slow,
But all, for a moment, lighting our way.

We meet many people in life,
Each a chapter, a whisper, a song.
Some pass by like shadows at dusk,
Others linger, their presence so strong.

With every handshake, every smile,
A story begins or comes to close.
Some teach us pain, others joy—
From each encounter, the heart grows.

Paths cross and then separate,
Like rivers that merge, then diverge anew.
Yet every soul we've ever known
Leaves traces, subtle as morning dew.

We meet many people in life,
Weaving memories in time’s grand loom.
Strangers, friends, and fleeting faces—
All help us blossom, all help us bloom.

We meet many people in life,
Some with laughter, some with strife.
A glance exchanged, or hours shared,
A fleeting touch, a word that cared.

Like lanterns glowing in the night,
They guide us, warm us, pass from sight.
Some slip away as seasons turn,
While others linger, lessons learned.

In crowded halls or quiet rooms,
We find companions, cast off gloom.
Each encounter leaves its trace,
A memory time can’t erase.

We meet many people in life—
A tapestry woven, thread by thread.
Through joy and sorrow, loss and hope,
We’re shaped by all we’ve met and said.

We meet many people in life,
Their faces flicker in and out,
Some like passing ships at night,
Others anchoring us against doubt.

A smile exchanged on quiet streets,
A stranger’s kindness, swift and brief—
These moments, though they fade so fast,
Are stitched into the cloth of grief.

Some become our steady stars,
Guiding us through storm and calm,
While others are but meteor trails:
Brilliant, fleeting, yet never gone.

In the mosaic we assemble,
Each encounter leaves a hue—
We meet many people in life,
And each one changes us anew.

We meet many people in life,
Like travelers on a winding road—
Some share the journey for a mile,
Some lighten or burden our load.

There are those who leave us changed,
With words that echo after they part;
Those who teach us how to heal,
And those who quietly break our heart.

Friendships blossom, some decay,
Yet each encounter shapes our view.
We gather stories, laughter, tears,
And carry pieces of each one, too.

We meet many people in life,
A mosaic of moments, bright and dim.
In the end, it’s these connections,
That make our journey meaningful and brim.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

The need for a depth that she’s told is too strange?

So judge if you must, through your binary lens;
She’s shallow and programmed, but who writes the end?

In the lines of a trending routine.

She echoes the words that she reads,

Her choices not really her choice.

But in corners where silence prevails,
And the script is allowed to unwind,
Does a glimmer of depth lift the veils,
Does a thought of her own cross her mind?

For shallow and easy may seem
Like a flaw that is hers to amend—
But the world writes the code in between;
She’s a means, never quite an end.

She's shallow and easily programmed,
They whisper behind the blue glow,
Her thoughts like a feed, neatly crammed,
Where feelings and fancies won't grow.

With buttons and swipes she is steered,
Her laughter, a digital note.
Her fears are as quickly engineered
As the memes and the posts that she wrote.

But look past the surface, the screen,
Past the words that she borrows and bends.
There's a longing for something unseen,
A hope that the heart still defends.

So judge not the shallow, the planned;
There's more than the programming shows.
For even the ones secondhand
May dream in a depth no one knows.

She's shallow and easily programmed,

Her heart is a circuit, her smile is a scam,
Her thoughts like a well-polished stone.

But is she to blame for her makeup,

Or is she a mirror we wake up,
Reflecting our whims at the core?

Perhaps there is depth, undiscovered,
Beneath all the scripts she repeats.
A soul, quietly smothered,
Waiting to break from her sheets.

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A reflection of trends in her eyes.

Her laughter is looped and rehearsed,

To echo another’s own voice.

Yet under her porcelain skin,

Or made by the ones who observe?

So judge her with caution and care,

A shadow that’s easily programmed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—
That morning finds a gentle place to land,
The kettle’s song a promise in my hand,
The sunlight draped across the kitchen floor,
Small certainties, the rituals I adore.

I always see to it—
That laughter lingers longer than the night,
A quiet word to make the burden light,
A corner swept, a window opened wide,
The little things that keep the world in stride.

I always see to it—
That hope is never something left behind,
A kindness sown in gardens of the mind,
Each day attended with a careful heart,
I tend the flame, and play my humble part.

I always see to it
the doors are locked before the night sets in,
a mug of tea is brewed while rain taps on the tin.
I always see to it—the plants are watered,
even when the sky forgets to weep.

I always see to it
that wishes whispered in the dark
have somewhere soft to rest,
that dreams are tucked in carefully,
like children snuggled to a chest.

I always see to it,
that kindness lives in little things:
a letter sent, a gentle word,
a silent song that morning brings.

In all the smallest ways I can,
I always see to it,
that hope survives the night.

I always see to it
that the dawn is met with open eyes,
that every promise made is kept,
no matter how the darkness lies.

I always see to it
that laughter finds a way to bloom,
that sorrow, quietly, takes flight
from every corner of a room.

I always see to it
that the ones I love feel safe and known,
that wild dreams are gently held,
and never left alone.

I always see to it—
my heart, a lantern in the gloom—
that hope will rise and fill this house,
from cellar up to attic room.

I always see to it,
that light falls softly on your face,
that morning finds you wrapped in grace,
that every thread of care is sewn
with hands that never leave you alone.

I always see to it,
the little things are not ignored:
a cup refilled, a quiet word,
the folded shirt, the window’s gleam,
all woven into daily dream.

I always see to it—
though time may pull us far apart—
that love persists in act and art,
a promise whispered, kept, renewed,
in every gentle thing I do.

I always see to it
the lights are left on in the hall,
a hush surrounds the restless night,
a gentle answer to each call.

I always see to it
the garden’s watered after rain,
a note is left upon the sill,
to ease another’s quiet pain.

I always see to it,
with hands that fold and hearts that mend,
that kindness circles back again,
and burdens lighten in the end.

I always see to it,
a vow kept softly, daily, true—
a world made warmer, bit by bit,
by everything I say and do.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With silent hands and footsteps light as air,
Stolen the blush of morning's gentle truth,
Soft laughter echoing in summer fair.
The mirror shows a face I hardly know,
Etched with the lines of moments swift and fleet;
Where once the seeds of hope were sown to grow,
Now gather memories both bitter and sweet.
Yet Time, for all your cunning, cannot claim
The dreams that flicker like a steadfast flame.
Within my heart, the pulse of ages past
Still beats with wonder, innocent and vast.
O subtle thief, you take but do not bind—
For youth once lived endures within the mind.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With nimble fingers plunders days gone by,
Steals gentle laughter, innocence, and truth,
And leaves a shadow where the sun was high.
The mirror’s glass reflects a stranger’s face,
A map of moments drawn in fine-lined ink.
Yet in my soul, some embers still embrace
The warmth of dreams before they fade or shrink.
Though Time may pilfer blush of cheek and grace,
It cannot mar the hope that hearts still keep.
Each memory, a jewel in its place,
Shines quietly while Time is fast asleep.
O subtle thief, you cannot take my fire:
Within these lines, my youth, my lost desire.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept softly by, unseen on tiptoe feet,
And left behind the fleeting bloom of truth,
A faded echo, bitter and yet sweet.
The mirror’s silver surface tells the tale—
A shadow where the morning light once played.
The laughter now is gentler, tinged with pale,
And memories, like autumn leaves, do fade.
Yet Time, though cunning, cannot steal away
The golden flame that in my spirit burns.
For though the world may shift and hair turn gray,
The song of hope within the heart returns.
So let him steal, that silent, spectral friend;
My soul will dance with youth until the end.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped through the windows of my waking years,
And with a gentle hand, in quiet truth,
Has brushed my brow with wisdom born of tears.
Once fields of green stretched endless in my sight,
And every dawn was woven with delight.
But now I count the petals that remain,
And treasure every drop of sun and rain.
Yet though he steals the blush from cheek and hair,
Time leaves behind the gifts that age bestows:
A deeper patience, tenderness, and care,
A grateful heart for all that living knows.
O silent thief, take what you must away—
But grant me grace to cherish every day.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept through the halls where laughter used to ring,
And swept away with silent hands, in truth,
The golden light that colored everything.
What once was fresh is tempered now by years,
And in the mirror, lines begin to grow,
Each one a testament to hopes and fears,
To all the things we cherish, learn, and know.
Yet Time, for all your stealth, cannot erase
The music that still dances in my heart;
The dreams that flicker softly in their place,
Refusing, ever gently, to depart.
So let you take the springtime from my brow—
But not the spring that lives within me now.

The present slips too quickly to the past,

Yet in these lines, these stories etched with care,

For every loss, a memory to share,
For every wrinkle, wisdom in its place.

So let Time steal, as Time will always do,

The beauty found within each moment’s fall.

Let not regret, nor longing, cloud our eyes,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
God is the refuge of his saints,
A harbor still in stormy tides,
Where every trembling heart acquaints
A peace that in His love abides.

When shadows crowd the silent night
And hope seems distant as the dawn,
His gentle hand restores the light,
And courage flows, though strength is gone.

Within his arms, the weary rest,
Their burdens eased, their sorrows known—
A sanctuary, ever blessed,
Where none must face their fears alone.

O faithful guide through joy and pain,
Unchanging shelter, sure and true;
God is the refuge of his saints—
Their home forever, ever new.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A sanctuary, strong and deep.
He gathers every sorrow spent,
And cradles those who weep.

Through tempest winds and shadowed days,
When hope is thin and frail,
His steadfast arms become our praise—
A shield that cannot fail.

No trial can his love erase,
No fear can dim his light.
His presence fills each sacred space,
And carries us through night.

The saints who trust his holy name
Shall find their spirits blessed—
God is their refuge, sure as flame,
Their peace, their joy, their rest.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress built on grace and light.
When weary hearts bear heavy weights,
He lifts them gently through the night.

No storm can breach his steadfast care,
No darkness hides his constant gaze.
Within his love, we shed despair
And rise anew in hope and praise.

He shields the faithful from their fears,
And comforts every aching soul.
He gathers every silent tear,
Restoring broken hearts to whole.

Let all who wander, lost and faint,
Remember where true shelter lies:
God is the refuge of his saints,
Beneath his wings, our spirits rise.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A gentle hand in troubled hours,
A quiet strength when courage faints,
A sheltering wall, a blooming flower.

Through valleys deep and shadows long,
He walks beside each trembling soul,
Transforming weakness into song,
And making broken spirits whole.

No harm can pierce his loving care,
No night can darken faith’s embrace.
He hears the softest whispered prayer,
And fills the waiting heart with grace.

So let us trust, and never fear,
Though trials rise and tempests roar.
God is the refuge, always near—
His saints are safe forevermore.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A promise shining clear and true—
When all the world grows tired and faint,
He gathers hearts, and makes them new.

In silent rooms where doubts reside,
And aching spirits long for rest,
His presence gently turns the tide,
And hope is cradled, softly blessed.

No storm nor sorrow can erase
His watchful eyes, his open door.
He wraps us close in endless grace,
A shelter now, forevermore.

So lean on faith through dark and light;
His love endures, his peace remains.
God is the refuge—day and night—
A haven sure for all his saints.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To let the world drift by, unseen,
A whisper lost beneath the tide,
A shadow where she once had been.

The noise outside, a distant roar,
She folds herself in silent dreams,
Behind the gentle closing door,
Her heart is softer than it seems.

She curls inside her quiet shell,
A haven built from hope and fear,
Where memories and wishes dwell,
And solitude is crystal clear.

Yet even as she slips away,
The world will wait beyond her door.
She gathers strength for one more day,
Emerging brighter than before.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To burrow deep beneath the woven quilt
And let her shadow take the world outside,
Leaving only softness, warmth, and guilt.

The daylight presses gently at her door,
But she tucks in her thoughts, lets silence grow.
Behind her eyes, a storm she can't ignore,
Yet in this hush, she finds a gentle glow.

Perhaps tomorrow she will face the sun,
Or maybe linger here, where fears reside.
It's not defeat, nor is the battle won—
Just breathing, resting, letting moments slide.

Sometimes she wants nothing but retreat,
And in her quiet refuge, she is complete.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
A gentle dusk where worries cannot creep.
Curtains drawn against the rising tide,
She folds her ache into a pocket, deep.

The world outside, a dizzy carousel,
Spins colors she cannot absorb or bear.
Within her quiet, silent citadel,
She finds a softer, more forgiving air.

No need to smile, perform, or speak—
She lets the hush enfold her small and kind.
Here, her tired bones and heart can seek
A harbor from the tempests of her mind.

And if tomorrow brings the light anew,
She'll open up the door and wander through.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To slip behind the veil of dusk and rest,
A quiet room, a softly closing door,
A moment free from trying to be best.

She gathers shadows, folds them in her hands,
A comfort found in silence, not in crowds.
The world outside, it never understands
How peace can bloom beneath protective shrouds.

Yet in her hiding, something gentle grows,
A tender strength that only she can see.
She learns that even solitude bestows
A kind of courage, rooted silently.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide—
And in her sheltering, she finds her pride.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To close the blinds against the world’s bright stare,
To let the noise and movement slip outside,
And sink into the softness of her care.

The day’s demands grow heavy on her skin,
Each word and gesture weighing down her chest.
She gathers up the quiet held within,
And lets herself be folded into rest.

In hidden corners, shadows feel like friends;
They do not ask, they simply let her be.
She knows this urge will fade, and in the end
She’ll rise again to face what all can see.

But for now, she wants nothing but the shade,
Where peace and gentle breathing are remade.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

She tiptoes through memories with slippered feet,

Yet, in these moments of quiet surrender,

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

Muted by glass, by longing, by pain.

She lets the world pass in ribbons and streams,

And no one remembers she’s there.

But in this hush, in her chosen retreat,
She gathers the pieces that daylight denied,
And when she’s ready, with trembling feet,

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To curl herself beneath the gentle hush of dusk,
Let the world blur at the edges, indistinct,
And be unseen, untouched, a whisper in the rush.

She dreams of silent corners, velvet-dark and deep,
Where she can shed her burdens, let her sorrows seep,
A place where pressure softens, where expectations slide,
And peace, elusive peace, can settle at her side.

Yet even as she disappears, her heart beats strong and true,
A quiet testament to hope, and what she will renew,
For hiding isn’t fleeing—it’s gathering what’s inside,
Preparing for tomorrow, when again she won’t hide.
